facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 11 of 1961 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 11 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the award dated January 7, 1960, of the Second Labour Court, West Bengal Calcutta, in case No. VIII-C/157 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal against award dated January 7, 1960 of Second Labour Court, West Bengal, Calcutta in case No. VIII-C/157 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated January 7, 1960, of the Second Labour Court, West Bengal Calcutta, in case No. VIII-C/157 of 1958. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India S. Andley, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 16, 1961 by SARKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. November 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-This is an appeal against the award of an industrial tribunal holding that the dismissal of two workmen by the appellant was unjustified and directing their reinstatement.

facts.text: Appellant has a factory for making yarn out of jute with Spinning and Batching departments.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has a factory for making yarn out of jute. There were, among others, two departments in the factory, namely the Spinning and the Batching departments.

facts.text: Ramdhani and Sitaram were Sardars employed in the Spinning Department.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen companycerned were Ramdhani and Sitaram and they were employed in the Spinning Department.

facts.text: On March 22, 1958, Roving Sardar Jagabandhu informed Ghosh, in charge of Batching Department, that Ramdhani was throwing away usable roving slivers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case is that on March 22, 1958, a Roving Sardar of the Batching Department called Jagabandhu informed Ghosh, who was in charge of that department, that Ramdhani was throwing away as unusable some workable roves  slivers of jute drawn out and slightly twisted  which came from the Batching Department to the Spinning Department.

facts.text: Ghosh went to Spinning Department and confirmed the report.

anchor.surface_text: Ghosh thereupon went to the Spinning Department and found that the report of the Roving Sardar was companyrect. He then asked the Roving Sardar to companylect the roves thrown away by Ramdhani for being placed before the appropriate authority for inspection.

facts.text: Ramdhani tried to prevent Jagabandhu from collecting the roves, took menacing attitude and abused Ghosh in filthy language.

anchor.surface_text: At this Ramdhani, who was a Sardar in the Spinning Department, tried to prevent the Roving Sardar from companylecting the roves. On Ghosh intervening, Ramdhani took a menacing attitude and abused him in filthy language.

facts.text: Sitaram, another Sardar, intervened, abused Ghosh and threatened him with violence.

anchor.surface_text: Soon, Sitaram, another Sardar of the Spinning Department, who had numberhing to do with the matter, came there and took the side of Ramdhani. He also abused Ghosh and further threatened him with violence.

facts.text: Ghosh complained to Management about the conduct.

anchor.surface_text: Ghosh companyplained to the Management of the factory about the companyduct of Ramdhani and Sitaram and the Management thereupon served charge-sheets on them.

facts.text: Management served charge-sheets stating abusive language and threat to assault Ghosh, guilty of misconduct under Standing Order No. 14(c)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The charge-sheets in substance stated that Ramdhani and Sitaram had used abusive and filthy language and threatened to assault Ghosh and they were, therefore, guilty of misconduct under Standing Order No. 14  c   i  of the Standing Orders of the appellant.

facts.text: Standing Order 14(c)(i): wilful insubordination or disobedience of lawful or reasonable order of superior.

anchor.surface_text: That Standing Order is in these terms 14 c -The following acts and omissions shall be treated as misconduct -  i -wilful insubordination, or disobedience, whether alone or in companybination with others, of any lawful or reasonable order a superior.

facts.text: Labour Officer held enquiry and found both accepted Jagabandhu's statement, guilty of insubordination.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the charge-sheets the appellants Labour Officer held an enquiry and came to the following findings Both Sitaram and Ramdhani accepted the statement of Jagabandhu the only witness of the incident. Jagabandhus statement clearly proves the offence of insubordination charged against Sitaram and Ramdhani.

facts.text: Enquiry found they refused to accept charge sheet and fomented stay-in strike on 24th and 25th March 1958.

anchor.surface_text: These two workmen companyld number place any witness or evidence by which it companyld be satisfied that they were number guilty. The refusal of acceptance of charge sheet is also another misconduct on the part of both these two workmen. Moreover, they number only refused to accept charge sheet to explain their companyduct but companymitted another very serious offence of fomenting and causing other Sardars to stage a stay in strike for two days on 24th and 25th March, 1958,

facts.text: Dismissal order issued further to charge sheet of 26-3-58, found guilty under 14-C(i), dismissed from service.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon passed the following order Further to the charge sheet issued to you on 26-3-58. I have found you guilty of misconduct under Rule 14-C I  of the certified standing orders. My decision is that you should be dismissed and I hereby dismiss you from the services of the companypany.

facts.text: Union raised industrial dispute on justification of dismissal, referred to tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The Union, the respondent in this appeal, then raised an industrial dispute as to whether the dismissal of Ramdhani and Sitaram was justified and this was referred by the Government to the tribunal resulting in the award earlier mentioned.

facts.text: Appellant conceded before tribunal that Ghosh was not supervisor of Spinning Department and not direct superior.

anchor.surface_text: It was companyceded by the appellant before the tribunal that Ghosh was number the supervisor of the Spinning Department where Ramdhani and Sitaram worked and was number, therefore, a direct superior of these workmen.

facts.text: Tribunal held dismissal unjustified as Ghosh not superior, so no insubordination under Standing Order 14(c)(i), directed reinstatement without back wages.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this admission by the appellant the tribunal observed that if Ramdhani and Sitaram disobeyed any orders of Ghosh they companyld number be held guilty of insubordination and disobedience within the Standing Order as Ghosh was number their superior. It came to the companyclusion that the decision of the enquiring officer of the appellant that these workmen were guilty of misconduct mentioned in Standing Order No.14 c  i  was, therefore, basically erroneous and companyld number be upheld. It thereupon directed the reinstatement of the dismissed workmen.

facts.text: Tribunal held refusal of charge sheets and strike not in charge-sheets, cannot consider for dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that the appellant had been influenced by the finding of the enquiry officer that the workmen companycerned had refused to accept the charge sheets and had caused a stay in strike. It observed that these offences were number the subject matter of the chargesheets and the appellant companyld number take them into companysideration in passing the order of dismissal.

facts.text: Tribunal treated period of unemployment as leave without pay as conduct not proper.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal further observed that the companyduct of the workmen was number proper and in that view of the matter refused to direct payment of their wages during the period of their forced unemployment, which period was, however, ordered to be treated as a period of leave without pay.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepted facts of appellant's case, no doubt workmen guilty of misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: Though the tribunal did number express any opinion as to the finding of fact by the enquiry officer of the appellant, it is clear that it accepted the same, otherwise it would number have disallowed the workmen their wages for the period of their forced unemployment on the ground that their companyduct had number been proper. We have gone through the evidence on the record and we feel number the slightest doubt that the case of the appellant was true. The two workmen had been guilty of the misconduct imputed to them.

facts.text: Supreme Court held misconduct falls within Standing Order 14(c)(i) as wilful insubordination.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether that misconduct came within the Standing Order No. 14  c  i . We are entirely unable to agree with the tribunal that the companyduct of the workmen did number amount to wilful insubordination.

facts.text: Ramdhani got weekly wages, not dependent on out-turn.

anchor.surface_text: Ramdhani got weekly wages as he admitted in his own evidence and therefore his wage did number depend on his out-turn.

facts.text: Dismissal order based only on charge finding, incidental matters connected.

anchor.surface_text: That order does number show that the order of dismissal had been based on any companysideration other than the finding on the charge brought against the workmen. In our view, an order of dismissal may be rightly sustained if it is based on a finding on a charge which the workmen companycerned had the opportunity of meeting even though in the companyrse of the enquiry other incidental matters had crept in.

facts.text: No victimisation found.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ramamurthy also argued that the order of dismissal was really an instance of victimisation and that this is in substance what the tribunal had found. We are entirely unable to accept this companytention. The workmen in their evidence had number suggested that they had been dismissed by way of victimisation and neither do we think that the tribunal had companye to any finding of victimisation.

anchor.surface_text: The Union, the respondent in this appeal, then raised an industrial dispute as to whether the dismissal of Ramdhani and Sitaram was justified and this was referred by the Government to the tribunal

concepts.unlisted_description: Dispute regarding justification of dismissal referred to tribunal

issues.text: Whether the misconduct imputed to the workmen (abusive language and threat to assault Ghosh) amounted to wilful insubordination under Standing Order No. 14(c)(i), even though Ghosh was not their direct superior

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether that misconduct came within the Standing Order No. 14  c  i . We are entirely unable to agree with the tribunal that the conduct of the workmen did not amount to wilful insubordination. It is clear to us that the Standing Order contemplates two types of misconduct one is wilful insubordination and the other is disobedience of any lawful and reasonable order of a superior.

issues.text: Whether the order of dismissal could be sustained based on the finding of guilt on the charged misconduct under Standing Order No. 14(c)(i), even though the enquiry report mentioned other incidental matters like refusal to accept charge-sheets and causing a stay-in-strike

anchor.surface_text: That order does not show that the order of dismissal had been based on any consideration other than the finding on the charge brought against the workmen. In our view, an order of dismissal may be rightly sustained if it is based on a finding on a charge which the workmen concerned had the opportunity of meeting even though in the course of the enquiry other incidental matters had crept in. One cannot take a too legalistic view in these matters.

issues.text: Whether the order of dismissal was an instance of victimisation

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ramamurthy also argued that the order of dismissal was really an instance of victimisation and that this is in substance what the tribunal had found. We are entirely unable to accept this contention. The workmen in their evidence had not suggested that they had been dismissed by way of victimisation and neither do we think that the tribunal had come to any finding of victimisation.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether that misconduct came within the Standing Order No. 14 c i . We are entirely unable to agree with the tribunal that the conduct of the workmen did not amount to wilful insubordination. It is clear to us that the Standing Order contemplates two types of misconduct one is wilful insubordination and the other is disobedience of any lawful and reasonable order of a superior.

arguments.claim: Wilful insubordination includes defiance of persons in authority whether direct superiors or not, and riotous conduct preventing higher officers from discharging duties

anchor.surface_text: In our view, insubordination would include defiance of persons in authority whether such persons were the direct superiors of the workmen charged or not. It would also include riotous conduct which made it impossible for the higher officers to discharge their duties properly.

holdings.text: We are entirely unable to agree with the tribunal that the conduct of the workmen did not amount to wilful insubordination.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether that misconduct came within the Standing Order No. 14 c i . We are entirely unable to agree with the tribunal that the conduct of the workmen did not amount to wilful insubordination. It is clear to us that the Standing Order contemplates two types of misconduct one is wilful insubordination and the other is disobedience of any lawful and reasonable order of a superior.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standing Order 14(c)(i) separates 'wilful insubordination' from 'disobedience of superior's order'; insubordination includes defiance of any authority person and riotous conduct preventing duties.

holdings.text: In our view, insubordination would include defiance of persons in authority whether such persons were the direct superiors of the workmen charged or not. It would also include riotous conduct which made it impossible for the higher officers to discharge their duties properly.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, insubordination would include defiance of persons in authority whether such persons were the direct superiors of the workmen charged or not. It would also include riotous conduct which made it impossible for the higher officers to discharge their duties properly. Mr. Ramamurthi for the Union said that insubordination was disobedience to a prescribed rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad purposive interpretation of insubordination beyond direct superiors; includes riotous acts and defiance thwarting authority.

holdings.text: an order of dismissal may be rightly sustained if it is based on a finding on a charge which the workmen concerned had the opportunity of meeting even though in the course of the enquiry other incidental matters had crept in.

anchor.surface_text: That order does not show that the order of dismissal had been based on any consideration other than the finding on the charge brought against the workmen. In our view, an order of dismissal may be rightly sustained if it is based on a finding on a charge which the workmen concerned had the opportunity of meeting even though in the course of the enquiry other incidental matters had crept in.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal based explicitly on charged misconduct under 14(c)(i); incidental connected matters corroborate charge and inform punishment; avoid legalistic view.

holdings.text: We are entirely unable to accept this contention [that the order of dismissal was really an instance of victimisation].

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ramamurthy also argued that the order of dismissal was really an instance of victimisation and that this is in substance what the tribunal had found. We are entirely unable to accept this contention. The workmen in their evidence had not suggested that they had been dismissed by way of victimisation and neither do we think that the tribunal had come to any finding of victimisation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No suggestion of victimisation by workmen in evidence; no tribunal finding to that effect.

holdings.text: We, therefore, think that the order of the tribunal cannot be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that the order of the tribunal cannot be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal justified under Standing Order 14(c)(i); tribunal erred in law on insubordination and incidental matters.
